com.ebay.redlasersdk.uicomponents
Class CameraPreviewLayout

java.lang.Object
  android.view.View
      android.view.ViewGroup
          android.widget.FrameLayout
              com.ebay.redlasersdk.uicomponents.CameraPreviewLayout
All Implemented Interfaces:
android.graphics.drawable.Drawable.Callback, android.view.accessibility.AccessibilityEventSource, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.ViewManager, android.view.ViewParent
public class CameraPreviewLayout
extends android.widget.FrameLayout

This view may be placed in your application's scan overlay, and tagged with the value "RedLaser Camera Preview Tag" make the RedLaser SDK place the camera preview SurfaceView inside this view. The SurfaceView will be sized to minimally cover the pixels in the CameraPrevieLayout, while maintaining the proper aspect ratio. This allows you to set up the scan activity show the camera preview only in part of the screen. In addition to setting the tag on this view, the application may override the getPreviewView() method of BarcodeScanActivity to indicate which view should host the camera preview. If you do neither of these things, the SDK will create a camera preview at the top level of the hierarchy, behind all other top level views--that is, a full-screen camera preview behind the entire overlay. Because the SDK shows the camera preview in a SurfaceView, there are several side effects of SurfaceViews that you should be aware of. The camera preview doesn't really interact with the view hierarchy; it punches a hole through the window and displays pixels directly. If you want to display another Surface while scanning, this may cause issues. Also, the OS relies on the gatherTransparentRegion method to determine the visible region of the SurfaceView. You probably should not put any other views inside of the CameraPreviewLayout; nor should you go too crazy with XML properties on the CameraPreviewLayout itself. Those things might work, but also might start not working with future releases. Really, you should think of this view as a way of indicating to the SDK where the camera preview should be placed.
